channel.title: NBC Sports Fantasy Football News
channel.description: Latest player news and analysis for fantasy football from NBC Sports.

item.title: NFL Network’s Ian Rapoport reports Jets RG Alijah Vera-Tucker (tricep) is expected to miss the 2025 season.
item.description: This was expected after ESPN’s Adam Schefter reported the torn tricep yesterday. Vera-Tucker was seeking a second opinion to confirm that season-ending surgery was necessary. It appears as though that is the case. The Jets will place him on injured reserve once the news is official. The Jets will likely move center Joe Tippmann to AVT’s spot and replace Tippmann with Josh Myers. For a team built on establishing a ball-control ground game, an early offensive line injury is not what Jets fans wanted to see ahead of Week 1.

item.title: NFL Network’s Ian Rapoport reports Cowboys CB Trevon Diggs will be on a “pitch count” for Week 1 against the Eagles.
item.description: Diggs suffered a season-ending knee injury and was at risk of missing multiple games to start the 2025 season. However, his recovery went better than expected and he was cleared to play in Week 1 on the Cowboys’ final injury report. As Rapoport notes, he won’t be getting his full complement of snaps, though expect to see the star corner out there for nearly every high-leverage play. Even with Diggs active, a Micah Parsons-less Dallas defense should scare fantasy managers off of starting any of the big names for Philly.

item.title: ESPN’s Adam Schefter reports Jets RG Alijah Vera-Tucker (tricep) will undergo season-ending surgery.
item.description: This confirms what both Schefter and the NFL Network’s Ian Rapoport had been reporting for the past day. AVT suffered the tricep injury during Tuesday’s practice and has been undergoing various tests to confirm the need for surgery ever since. Vera-Tucker was set to play 2025 on his fifth-year option but will now head to free agency after spending the entire season on injured reserve. Vera-Tucker has ended three of the past four seasons on injured reserve and has appeared in just 43-of-85 possible games since entering the league in 2021. Even with a checkered injury history, his play should earn him a healthy contract on the open market.

item.title: Panthers OC Brad Idzik said the team doesn’t want to “run Chuba Hubbard dry” early in the season.
item.description: Hubbard was a workhorse for the Panthers last year, running for 1,195 yards on 250 attempts. He also totaled 43 receptions for another 171 yards, bringing him over 275 touches for the second season in a row. The team rewarded him for his efforts with a four-year extension midseason, but that doesn’t mean they are going to load him up with touches once again. The Panthers brought in Rico Dowdle in free agency and spent a fourth-round pick on Trevor Etienne. Dowdle split snaps with Hubbard during the preseason, alluding to a possible role for him on passing downs. Hubbard remains the only back with stand-alone fantasy value in Carolina, but he may struggle to live up to his lofty ADP if Dowdle or Etienne are more involved than expected.

item.title: Giants restructured LT Andrew Thomas’s contract.
item.description: It’s likely a simple restructuring, converting future base salary into a signing bonus that is prorated over the life of the deal. Per ESPN’s Field Yates, the move creates $12.2 million in cap space. Thomas signed a five-year, $117.5 million contract extension in 2023. He remains under contract through 2029.

item.title: Broncos signed EDGE Nik Bonitto to a four-year, $106 million contract extension.
item.description: According to ESPN’s Adam Schefter, the deal is worth “up to” $120 million, with $70 million fully guaranteed. Bonitto is now the highest-paid non-quarterback in franchise history for Denver. A former second-round pick, Bonitto has gotten better every year of his career, culminating in a breakout 2024 headlined by 13.5 sacks. He added a pair of forced fumbles, one fumble recovery for a touchdown, and a pick-six to his ledger as well. Bonitto is one of several high-impact defenders that make the Broncos’ defense one of the best in the league. They get to tee off on rookie quarterback and No. 1 overall pick Cam Ward for the 2025 opener this week.

item.title: Travis Kelce said he is feeling “young and ready to rock” when asked if 2025 could be his last season in the NFL.
item.description: He also noted that 2025 is the final year of his current contract. Kelce is still a top-end tight end, but his play has been on the decline in recent seasons, leaving him well outside of the elite tier he used to rule over. Between his engagement to Taylor Swift and his blossoming media presence, Kelce also has plenty of ventures to keep him occupied outside of football if he chooses to hang up the cleats. Whether or not he retires will likely come down to how the season ends for Kansas City. Kelce is a three-time Super Bowl champion with two additional losses, the most recent of which was handed to him by Philadelphia last season. Another win could send him out on the ultimate high note. For now, Kelce is on to Week 1 for a date with the Chargers on Friday. He remains a volume-based TE1, especially with Rashee Rice serving a six-game suspension to begin the season.

item.title: Seahawks signed RT Abraham Lucas to a three-year, $46 million contract extension.
item.description: Per NFL Network’s Mike Garafolo, Lucas can also earn more money via incentives. He was set for a contract year before inking the long-term deal. The former third-round pick had a solid rookie season but has since seen his career bogged down by injuries. Lucas has appeared in just 13 games over the past two seasons after taking the field for 16 starts in 2022. Lucas’s deal is relatively affordable for a starting tackle, with the incentives likely giving Lucas a chance to improve both his play and his salary over the next few seasons.

item.title: Bills signed K Matt Prater to the practice squad.
item.description: Tyler Bass is dealing with a groin injury and was limited in Wednesday’s practice. Prater will be called up from the practice squad if Bass can’t suit up for Week 1. Prater went 6-of-6 on his field goal tries with the Cardinals in 2024 before missing the remainder of the season with a torn meniscus.

item.title: Giants LT Andrew Thomas (foot) did not practice Thursday.
item.description: Head coach Brian Daboll said Thomas looked good yesterday during his limited session. It’s possible his DNP today is just maintenance or a precaution, but it’s still an ominous start to the season for Russell Wilson’s blindside protector. Jordan Hudson would enter the starting lineup if Thomas is unable to suit up for Week 1.
